name: Rand Paul
content:
On this #WasteReportWednesday we examine how your government lost more than 100+ ScanEagle drones...

So, what exactly happened this time around? In March 2015, the Combined Security Transition Command – Afghanistan (CSTC-A), the name for the American-led coalition organization tasked with building Afghanistan’s capacity to independently handle its internal and external security, recognized that the ANA was unable to conduct intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) operations on their own, without U.S. and coalition forces. To fix the ANA’s credibility gap, DOD entered into five contracts with a contractor with the goal of having the contractor improve and supplement the ANA’s capabilities, as well as train the ANA to be self-sufficient in ISR operations. All told, DOD purchased 16,000 assets from the contractor, including 105 drones.

DOD charged Naval Air Systems Command (NAVAIR) to oversee the five contracts and ensure the contractor fulfilled its end of the bargain. But, NAVAIR failed to designate individuals to serve as touchpoints between the contractor and DOD both in country and in general, contravening DOD protocols on contract administration, so there was nobody to ensure the contractor fulfilled its responsibility. Clearly, those touchpoints were necessary, because when the Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction (SIGAR) reviewed the contracts, it found that NAVAIR was unable to produce evidence that the contractor completed 122 of the 403 deliverables of the entire contract with the contractor, not just the drones for which DOD contracted, amounting to about 30 percent of unverifiable deliverables.

According to SIGAR, “CSTC-A and NAVAIR said the ANA is responsible for ScanEagle system logistics. However, the ANA is not tracking the real-time location of ScanEagle equipment across Afghanistan ... [and CSTC-A officials] are concerned that the ANA does not know where the equipment it owns is located or whether it is being used appropriately.”

In layman’s terms? As of late July 2020, “it appears neither DOD nor the ANA can say with certainty where each ScanEagle vehicle is currently located.

name: Rand Paul
content:
Another addition to #WasteReportWednesday, let’s see look at what Dr. Fauci and the National Institute of Health have been up to…

Have you put off that trip to the dentist because you’re scared?

Bet you have canceled a dentist appointment — you didn’t want a lecture on flossing, or you (and your check book) were scared there was a cavity to be found? Most of us have been there.

There’s even a word for fear of the dentist: dentophobia! Well, never fear, the federal government is here! And it’s spending your money to bankroll researchers at Temple University as they see whether telling you not to be scared of the dentist will get you over your fears so you keep your appointment.

As unbelievable as it may seem, researchers are two years into a five-year (yes, five full years) study in which it will test if “a brief Internet-based cognitive behavioral intervention for the treatment of impairing dental anxiety among those seeking dental care” will actually alleviate anxiety about going to the dentist. In other words, researchers are trying to answer the question, if you watch a video saying ‘don’t be scared of the dentist’ an hour before your appointment, will it help you not be scared of the dentist? Only thing is, the message is sent to you an hour before the appointment.

Many dentists require at least 24-hour notice for cancelations. So, one would assume most people have discussed whether to skip the chair, the bib, and the swish and spit much earlier. Moreover, with our nation facing $1 trillion deficits as far as the eye can see, the NIH perhaps should focus its efforts on helping to fix that financial cavity, and leave the ones in our mouths to our dentists.

#stopthewaste

name: Tammy Duckworth
content:
One of the best ways for our nation to strengthen our competitiveness with the rest of the world is to enhance a crown jewel of American innovation: the incredible network of Department of Energy National Labs, particularly Illinois’ own Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory and Argonne National Laboratory.

I’m proud to have worked with Senator Ben Ray Luján to get our important bipartisan amendment included in the United States Innovation and Competition Act so we can invest in the National Science Foundation and enhance our National Labs, which are critical drivers of American innovation and capable of advancing even more groundbreaking scientific research and discovery.

name: Adam B. Schiff
content:
President Biden’s decision to withdraw American troops from Afghanistan is the right choice for our national security and for the security of our men and women in uniform. But unless we take immediate action, more than 17,000 Afghan allies who served alongside American troops as translators, engineers, security guards, embassy clerks, and advisors will remain in danger — living under threat of retaliatory violence by groups like the Taliban, ISIS, and Al Qaeda.

That’s why I joined a bipartisan group of colleagues to call on the Biden administration to honor our commitments to our Afghan allies and evacuate them to safety.

Read the letter: https://moulton.house.gov/download/moultons-afghanistan-letter-to-president-biden

name: Jeff Merkley
content:
Growing up, my dad’s job as a union machinist was enough to buy a modest house, pay our family's bills, and take us on annual camping vacations. But since then, costs of education, health care, and housing have gone through the roof and wages have flat lined, making stories like my family's fewer and farther between.

Folks think our tax system is rigged in favor of the mega rich—because it is. The powerful and privileged have spent decades bending Congress to acquire tax giveaway after tax giveaway, while cutting investments in the things working families need to thrive, like living wage jobs, affordable health care, a good education, and a home they can afford. The evidence is overwhelming: we need a Wealth Tax in America to level the playing field and make sure that top billionaires pay their fair share.

NYTIMES.COM
Wealthiest Executives Paid Little to Nothing in Federal Income Taxes, Report Says

Did you know that 74% of European countries entirely ban absentee voting? Or that 46 of 47 European countries require a government-issued photo voter ID to vote? The only one that doesn't? The United Kingdom. And even there, legislation was recently introduced to do so.

If you believe all states should have voter ID, SHARE THIS ARTICLE! We must restore faith in elections and the voting process nationwide.

name: Ralph Norman
content:
The numbers are not good. 1,194 people participated in the survey I posted a few days ago on inflation. Over 80% of respondents are being impacted by rising prices. Here’s the breakdown:

*****

49.5% said, “I’ve noticed higher prices. I can still afford everything I need, but am starting to cut back on non-essential purchases.”

32.3% said, “I’ve noticed higher prices, and am concerned I may not be able to afford the things I need.”

12.6% said, “I’ve noticed higher prices, but am still able to afford the things I need and want.”

5.6% said, “I have not perceived an increase in prices of the goods and services I normally purchase.”

*****

It wasn’t a scientific poll, obviously, but in terms of getting a general sense of public opinion, there is absolutely no question that an overwhelming majority of people have needed to make very real adjustments to their lives to accommodate these price increases.

There are lots of reasons why we’re experiencing inflation, some of which are temporary. Some of which cannot be easily controlled. And some of which are industry specific. But one thing is for sure:

Trillions of additional spending that Democrats (and a few Republicans) want – on top of what it normally costs to operate the federal government – is only going to make inflation worse.

name: Sam Graves
content:
Doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result is the definition of insanity.

Yet, that’s exactly what Speaker Pelosi is doing with this infrastructure bill.

Last year, she rammed a completely partisan surface transportation bill down our throats. It went nowhere. It did nothing.

Now, she’s doing the same thing again. This time with even more wasteful Green New Deal spending and less emphasis on fixing our infrastructure.

This isn’t “transformative” or “visionary,” it’s passing the buck. It’s kicking the can down the road and hoping someone someday has the courage to get a real bipartisan bill done.

Americans have had enough of politics as usual in Washington. We don’t need to double down on what didn’t work last year.

We need to work together to get a real bipartisan bill done. That’s what the President promised the American people and that’s what we should be working towards.

A great place to start would be focusing on fixing REAL infrastructure in America. After all, you’ve got to build bridges to build bridges.

name: Dan Sullivan
content:
Early in the pandemic, when critical supplies and personal protective equipment were in short supply, Taiwan sent over 10 million masks to the United States that said “Love from Taiwan”—an indication of the strong, supportive relationship America has with this island democracy.

Unlike the United States, Taiwan is still in the throes of the pandemic with limited access to safe and effective vaccines due to the influence of the Chinese Communist Party.

On Sunday, I wore one of Taiwan’s masks in Taipei to express our gratitude as we announced 750,000 vaccines—what I called “Love from America”—for our friends and partners.

name: James M. Inhofe
content:
Today, two former managers at a major property management firm pleaded guilty for their roles in a scheme to defraud the U.S. Air Force in connection with privatized military housing contracts, including at Tinker AIr Force Base in Oklahoma.

When Sen Reed and I first heard reports of alleged falsified records back in July 2019, we were disturbed. Now that the Department of Justice is involved, and has found that this fraud was carried out at the direction of company leadership, and that due to such fraudulent actions, ‘substantial parts of the housing community fell into disrepair, leaving service members living in substandard conditions,’ we are absolutely outraged. At the same time, we are glad justice is being served, and want to reiterate our commitment to doing right by our military families. As leaders of the Senate Armed Services Committee, we will be keeping a close eye on the results of this case, which remains ongoing as we do not know how high up this conspiracy may go.

Should any other charges pan out, we expect all criminals involved to be held accountable to the fullest extent of the law. With the help of the Department of Justice, the Department of Defense and military services must work to ensure this never happens again.

Military housing companies must take every step to regain the trust of our military families. An easy place to start is finalizing the Housing Bill of Rights and making sure it includes three key elements as we directed in the Fiscal Year 2020 National Defense Authorization Act: dispute resolution, a common lease, and ability to withhold rent. It’s been well over one year since this was signed into law — and more than two years since our first hearing on the matter — and it’s unacceptable that DOD has once again delayed formalizing these critical protections for our military families. After hearing countless complaints from military families starting over two years ago, we led the charge to address widespread problems with military housing, and we are determined to see this through on behalf of those brave families.
text: today two former managers major property management firm pleaded guilty roles scheme defraud us air force connection privatized military housing contracts including tinker air force base oklahomawhen sen reed first heard reports alleged falsified records back july disturbed department justice involved found fraud carried direction company leadership due fraudulent actions substantial parts housing community fell disrepair leaving service members living substandard conditions absolutely outraged time glad justice served want reiterate commitment right military families leaders senate armed services committee keeping close eye results case remains ongoing know high conspiracy may goshould charges pan expect criminals involved held accountable fullest extent law help department justice department defense military services must work ensure never happens againmilitary housing companies must take every step regain trust military families easy place start finalizing housing bill rights making sure includes three key elements directed fiscal year national defense authorization act dispute resolution common lease ability withhold rent well one year since signed law two years since first hearing matter unacceptable dod delayed formalizing critical protections military families hearing countless complaints military families starting two years ago led charge address widespread problems military housing determined see behalf brave families

name: Jeff Merkley
content:
With over 50% of American adults fully vaccinated, we’ve made significant progress on vaccinations in the United States. To reduce the potential for dangerous variants and protect that progress here at home, we must dramatically expand vaccine production, access, and equity for the rest of the world.

Last week, the Biden Administration announced a plan to distribute surplus vaccine doses—a good first step. But vaccine dose sharing in the millions isn’t going to cut it if we want to help end a pandemic jeopardizing the health of billions of people globally who have yet to be fully vaccinated. We need specific and ambitious goals, timelines, and targets to get folks around the world vaccinated, meet the true scale of this current crisis, and establish the infrastructure to prevent and respond to pandemics that may arise in the future.

MERKLEY.SENATE.GOV
Merkley, Colleagues Introduce Bicameral Bill to Protect U.S. From Risk of New Coronavirus Strains By Defeating Virus Abroad | U.S. Senator Jeff Merkley of Oregon

name: James M. Inhofe
content:
As ranking members of the House and Senate Armed Services Committees, Congressman Mike D. Rogers and I are very concerned about recent reports that an Acting Secretary of the Navy would cancel a new Nuclear Sea Launched Cruise Missile after submission of the FY22 budget, and before a Nuclear Posture Review has been started — much less completed. The Biden administration has decided to project weakness ahead of a summit with Vladimir Putin – another gift to our adversaries. We have serious questions for senior Pentagon leaders on this reported decision and how it was reached.

name: Adam B. Schiff
content:
Investing in our nation’s infrastructure is the strongest way to both revitalize our economy and ensure we are ready for the future – and I’m proud to announce that the recently introduced transportation funding package, the INVEST in America Act, includes $20 million for seven important transportation and infrastructure projects throughout California’s 28th Congressional District.

From expanding electric vehicle charging stations in Burbank, to making roads and sidewalks safer for drivers, pedestrians, and bikers in Glendale and West Hollywood, to protecting against erosion in La Cañada and more, these improvements will enhance the safety, green sustainability, and quality of life across our community.

Infrastructure is more than just roads and bridges. It’s about investing in people and how they live — and I’m confident that we will pass a major transportation infrastructure package this year.

Read the full descriptions of community projects I successfully requested funding for here: https://schiff.house.gov/news/press-releases/schiff-announces-inclusion-of-20-million-for-local-priorities-in-transportation-and-infrastructure-investment-legislation

name: Roger F. Wicker
content:
Republicans and Democrats can agree that all people deserve equal pay for equal work. In fact, pay discrimination based on gender has long been prohibited by federal law. The poorly conceived provisions of the Paycheck Fairness Act would do little to strengthen these existing protections.

More troublingly, this legislation included language that I fear would compel businesses, including religious organizations, to pay for abortion services. I could not in good conscience support the Paycheck Fairness Act.

name: Steve Cohen
content:
To all my GOP colleagues hemming and hawing about bipartisanship, know that the infrastructure bill IS bipartisan. The INVEST in America Act enjoys bipartisan public support like the Rescue Plan and 1/6 Commission that came before it.

It’s been decades since the last transformational infrastructure bill and as a result we've fallen behind. The Memphis bridge closure is a canary in the coal mine but others lie in disrepair. We must pass this bill to repair our infrastructure, build for the future and create jobs.

I’m proud the bill includes funds for Memphis as well as bills I authored involving interstate rail compacts, complete streets, school bus safety, impaired driving, underride guards, Amtrak dining car service and the renaming of the Selma-to-Montgomery highway after John Lewis.

name: Ken Calvert
content:
We have a hard time preventing crime and homelessness in our own major cities, so I am not optimistic about the Vice President’s efforts to solve the border crisis by “fixing” the conditions in other countries. I also don’t believe her pleas to “not come” are going to stop the flood of illegal immigrants overwhelming the border. I believe we must fix our broken immigration system, mandate the use of E-Verify, have people apply for asylum in their own country or in the nearest country where it’s safe, reform our visa programs to address overstays, and complete the physical barrier along our southern border. We want people to come here legally, not illegally. In the end, the best way to deter illegal immigration is by having a system of laws and enforcement that send a loud message that those who come here illegally will not be able to stay.

NPR.ORG
Harris Wanted To Talk About Migration, But Instead Got Pushed About A Border Visit

name: Bill Johnson
content:
The Washington County Farm Bureau held a meeting yesterday morning at the Barlow Fairgrounds where I gave a brief legislative update before we discussed a variety of issues impacting our community. The Sheriff’s Department discussed a possible return to community-based crime stop (also called neighborhood watch) programs. We also talked about several issues affecting farmers, ranchers, and producers including: the lack of broadband internet access in rural areas; the potential for major tax increases by the Biden Administration; and the longstanding concerns surrounding the consolidated meat packing industry.

Small cattle producers – and there are many in Eastern and Southeastern Ohio – have experienced significant market volatility over the last year and a half due to the pandemic and other variables. In fact, the price for live cattle in the United States has decreased in the last several years while the price of boxed beef has increased significantly, raising consumer prices.

This morning, I sent a letter to Attorney General Merrick Garland regarding the issue. In May 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice Antitrust Division began investigating the four largest meat packers for anticompetitive conduct. Yet, more than a year later Congress has not received an update on this investigation. Ohio’s cattle producers need an update to help ensure confidence in our commodity markets. We must ensure that our nation’s farmers, ranchers, and producers operate in fair and transparent markets, because they are the ones that put food on American tables.

name: John Boozman
content:
Today the Biden administration announced its intent to repeal the Navigable Waters Protection rule to define Waters of the United States (WOTUS).

Eliminating the certainty of the Trump-era WOTUS rule threatens the livelihoods of hardworking Americans. The idea that Washington bureaucrats are better positioned than state and local jurisdictions to regulate water quality is an attack on farmers, ranchers and homeowners. I will continue to defend the current rule and fight this Biden administration power grab.

In January, my colleagues and I introduced a resolution in support of upholding the Navigable Waters Protection rule. As a member of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works (EPW), I have repeatedly fought against the Obama-era WOTUS rule and advocated for water rules that provide certainty for agriculture producers and all landowners.

https://www.boozman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?id=686A0F07-E853-4BF8-9DAB-6DE342E6D0F3

BOOZMAN.SENATE.GOV

name: Angus S. King, Jr.
content:
America’s philanthropic sector is a global force for good – but to maximize its impact, we must reform tax rules that govern some gifts. I am introducing a bill with Senator Chuck Grassley to ensure all donations reach working charities in a reasonable timeframe.

Under current rules, donor-advised funds (or DAFs) and private foundations allow some Americans to receive tax breaks for donations that never actually reach working charities. Our bill will clarify this gray area by instituting time limits on how long DAFs can hold money meant for charitable donations, providing incentives for faster distribution of these funds, and guaranteeing that payments to a donor's family don’t count as eligible expenses for private foundations.

These are commonsense changes – with bipartisan support – that can provide free up much-needed resources for the philanthropic organizations that play vital roles in communities across America. Let’s pass this bill, and make sure that charitable donations actually reach charities.

NYTIMES.COM
How Long Should It Take to Give Away Millions?
text: americas philanthropic sector global force good maximize impact must reform tax rules govern gifts introducing bill senator chuck grassley ensure donations reach working charities reasonable timeframeunder current rules donoradvised funds dafs private foundations allow americans receive tax breaks donations never actually reach working charities bill clarify gray area instituting time limits long dafs hold money meant charitable donations providing incentives faster distribution funds guaranteeing payments donors family dont count eligible expenses private foundationsthese commonsense changes bipartisan support provide free muchneeded resources philanthropic organizations play vital roles communities across america lets pass bill make sure charitable donations actually reach charitiesnytimescomhow long take give away millions

name: Lisa Murkowski
content: I recently visited the Kanakanak Hospital, a 16-bed, 24-hour medical facility in Dillingham. I appreciate the workers for showing me around the hospital and talking me through their pandemic response efforts—including their altered processes for patient intake, their modified surge plan, and the success they had treating patients with high flow nasal cannulas. As I continue conversations with the Senate HELP Committee about what we’ve learned from the COVID-19 pandemic and how we can become better prepared for the future, hearing firsthand from Alaskans about their needs and priorities is invaluable.

name: Terri Sewell
content:
While we've made great progress in the last six months, the pandemic is not over, and families in my district and across the country are still struggling.

I am deeply concerned that governors are denying unemployment compensation to the families that need our support the most. That's why I joined Congressman Bill Pascrell, Jr. in requesting an analysis of the economic damages that Americans will incur as a result. Before cutting off critical assistance, we must have a better understanding of the barriers that are slowing down a return to work, including access to child care and workplace safety.

name: Ann Wagner
content:
I am excited to announce our Suburban Caucus Task Force Chairs for the 117th Congress.

As Joe Biden and Nancy Pelosi continue to push liberal policies that threaten the economic security of American families, it is critical we push back against their dangerous ideas. The Suburban Caucus is poised to do just that by crafting and promoting common sense legislation that will stand as a stark contrast to the Democrats’ radical agenda.

In the first five months of Joe Biden’s Administration we have already seen higher prices at the grocery store, and the highest gas prices in years. The Socialist ideas coming out of Joe Biden’s Administration are hurting Missouri families and they must be challenged. I am ready to work with our Task Force Chairs on behalf of American and Missouri families who need our help in this perilous time.

name: Mike Thompson
content: In case you missed it, earlier this week I announced that our district has $19.03 million in Federal funding that I requested included in the upcoming infrastructure bill. This includes $742,000 for the San Pablo Avenue Rehabilitation in Pinole in Contra Costa County, $2.28 million for the Chip Seal Program in Lake County, $3 million for the Napa Valley Vine Trail in Napa County, $4 million for the State Route 37/Fairgrounds Drive Interchange project in Solano County, $2 million for the Highway 116/West Cotati Intersection Safety Improvement project in Sonoma County and $7 million for the State Route 37 Corridor Enhancement Program in Sonoma County. This legislation is being considered in the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee today and still needs to be approve by the full House and Senate and signed into law by President Biden.

name: Garret Graves
content:
I recently visited the southern border to assess the border crisis in Texas and New Mexico. Check out how some ports of the border wall remain unfinished.

We need border security and to fix our broken immigration system. Protecting our borders is essential to our national security. A secure border will help prevent illegal crossings, terrorist attacks, and the unlawful trafficking of persons and drugs.

That said, there's no silver bullet solution to border security. In some cases, physical structures such as walls and fencing will secure our border. In other areas, enhanced surveillance, increased border patrols, and other measures will be required. To genuinely secure our border, we must constantly adapt our tactics.

Failure to enforce our laws and secure our borders creates a perverse incentive for people to come here illegally and can cause delays in the process for those who want to come here the right way. I will continue working with the Administration and with my colleagues in Congress to make sure we effectively enforce our immigration laws.
text: recently visited southern border assess border crisis texas new mexico check ports border wall remain unfinishedwe need border security fix broken immigration system protecting borders essential national security secure border help prevent illegal crossings terrorist attacks unlawful trafficking persons drugsthat said theres silver bullet solution border security cases physical structures walls fencing secure border areas enhanced surveillance increased border patrols measures required genuinely secure border must constantly adapt tacticsfailure enforce laws secure borders creates perverse incentive people come illegally cause delays process want come right way continue working administration colleagues congress make sure effectively enforce immigration laws

name: David P. Joyce
content:
It was truly an honor to present two American heroes, Mr. Gale Lanning and Specialist Rodney Stevens, with their long overdue military medals yesterday. The Lanning and Stevens families were so proud to see their loved ones recognized for their service to our country 🇺🇸 Many thanks to Ohio National Guard’s Maj. Robinson and SFC Frederickson for joining us for this special occasion.

Mr. Lanning was awarded the Bronze Star Medal, Army Commendation Medal, National Defense Service Medal, Vietnam Service Medal, Republic of Vietnam Campaign Ribbon, and the Sharpshooter Badge.

Specialist Stevens was awarded the Purple Heart, Army Commendation Medal, National Defense Service Medal, Vietnam Service Medal, Combat Infantryman Badge, Republic of Vietnam Campaign Ribbon, Expert Badge, Sharpshooter Badge, and the Marksman Badge.

God bless our veterans!

name: Lisa Murkowski
content:
The Department of Defense (DoD) just announced that it is establishing the Ted Stevens Center for Arctic Security Studies, an effort that I pushed legislatively and worked to fund. This will be the first ever DoD Regional Center focused on the Arctic. I’m encouraged to see Senator Sullivan and my efforts come one step closer to fruition. I was pleased to hear directly from Secretary Austin that he is moving forward with its establishment. Given the growing importance of the Arctic in global geopolitical and strategic affairs, the Stevens Center will provide DoD a place to foster the research and dialogue critical to national security especially as it pertains to the Arctic region. I continue to stress that the Stevens Center must be based in Alaska – near the Arctic and at the geostrategic crossroads of the world – and look forward to working with DoD to continue moving in that direction.

MURKOWSKI.SENATE.GOV
DoD Announces the Establishment of Arctic Regional Center | U.S. Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska

name: Chris Van Hollen
content:
Transparency is necessary to ensure greater accountability in policing. That’s why it is important to collect ALL of the data that can reveal patterns of inappropriate or unlawful use of force. Participation in the FBI’s use of force data collection program is abysmal, which is why I pressed Attorney General Garland today to acknowledge that federal law enforcement should lead by example on this issue by reporting all of their data. I was glad to hear his commitment to do so. It’s vital that the FBI take further action to improve participation around the country, so that we can use this crucial information to support and guide our efforts on police reform.

WASHINGTONPOST.COM
For a second year, most U.S. police departments decline to share information on their use of force

name: John Barrasso
content:
The Biden administration continues its crusade to replace sound regulatory policy reforms with misguided federal mandates and job-killing uncertainty. The #WOTUS rule was a terrible idea during the Obama administration and it certainly hasn’t improved with age. #WOTUS isn’t about protecting our waterways. It’s about giving Washington control over everything from backyard ponds to puddles & farm fields. I’ll stand with America’s farmers, ranchers, and landowners to oppose this misguided rule every step of the way.

BARRASSO.SENATE.GOV
Biden Admin Wants to Give Washington Control of Wyoming’s Water - News Releases - United States Senator John Barrasso

name: Stephanie N. Murphy
content:
BREAKING: As we approach the 5-year anniversary of the Pulse shooting this weekend, the Senate just passed our bill to designate a #PulseNationalMemorial to honor the 49 innocent lives that were taken from us that terrible day.

Proud to have worked on this important legislation with Representatives Darren Soto and Val Demings. #ForThe49

U.S. Congresswoman Stephanie Murphy
May 12 at 3:08 PM ·

Excited that our bill to designate #Pulse as a National Memorial site just passed the House. This is about more than building a monument to mourn those we lost. It will be a physical reminder that our work won’t be complete until we ensure the lives of the victims were not lost in vain. 🏳️‍🌈

name: Scott H. Peters
content:
Our roads, bridges and transit systems are in dire need of updates. We must also prepare our electric grid and broadband to meet 21st-century demands.

One party cannot undertake these tasks alone. That's why I and my Problem Solvers Caucus colleagues released the #BuildingBridges framework.

Our proposal provides Congress a roadmap to find common ground on #infrastructure policy that delivers for the American people. It illustrates that compromise is possible and a positive step to advance bipartisan conversations.

Read more about this proposal here: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/09/us/politics/house-infrastructure-proposal.html

NYTIMES.COM
A bipartisan group of House lawmakers unveils an infrastructure proposal.

name: Doug Lamborn
content:
I just finished touring Monument Academy’s new (east) high school campus and learned about the outstanding curriculum, teachers, and support they offer to students at their schools. Their goal as educators is to provide a safe, fun, and student-focused atmosphere that partners with parents to ensure each child in their care thrives. Charter schools such as Monument Academy have done a fantastic job at safely and efficiently keep their doors open to students during the Covid-19 pandemic. ﻿

Thank you to Laura Carno, Bill Cadman, Sandra Bankes, Aaron Salt, Eric Davis, Carolyn Martin, and Rick Van Weiren for joining us and discussing your successes and concerns as school board members, facilitators, and educators across El Paso County.

And special thanks to Julie Seymour, Charlie Richardson, Melanie Strop, and Ryan Graham for hosting my staff and me at your impressive new campus!

name: Debbie Wasserman Schultz
content:
Every year in Florida, too many children die from drowning, and sadly, statistics show the Sunshine State leads the nation among children younger than 5 years old. So far this year, 37 children have died statewide, including seven in Broward County.

To better educate children and adults about ways to prevent these tragedies, I’m joined by Dr. Peter Antevy, an emergency room physician with Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital, and Cassie McGovern from Florida Department of Health Broward County, to discuss these issues.

name: Brian Schatz
content:
NEWS: Yesterday, the Senate passed the provisions I authored to strengthen ties between the U.S. and Pacific Island nations.

We have deep ties to these communities grounded in our shared commitment to respecting human rights and the rule of law, protecting marine resources, and combating the global climate crisis. The provisions I authored in the bill firm up our foreign policy commitment to Pacific Island nations by ensuring that we are aligning all the tools of U.S. diplomacy to strengthen people-to-people ties and support the economic needs and long-term resilience goals of our allies and partners in the region.

SCHATZ.SENATE.GOV
Schatz Provisions To Strengthen U.S.-Oceania Ties In United States Innovation And Competition Act Passes Senate | U.S. Senator Brian Schatz of Hawaii

name: John Garamendi
content:
America needs a modern transportation and infrastructure system that builds for the future and creates millions of new middle-class jobs in the process.

Today, we are taking a major step forward to realize that goal. The House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee is advancing the INVEST in America Act--a comprehensive bill to rebuild our crumbling transportation infrastructure with American materials and workers. As a senior member of the committee, I secured over $20 million in new federal funding as part of this bill to support transportation priorities in our Congressional District.

I look forward to voting the INVEST in America Act out of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee today, and will vote to pass it in the House of Representatives in the coming weeks.

Read more below:

TRANSPORTATION.HOUSE.GOV
INVEST in America | The House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure
text: america needs modern transportation infrastructure system builds future creates millions new middleclass jobs processtoday taking major step forward realize goal house transportation infrastructure committee advancing invest america acta comprehensive bill rebuild crumbling transportation infrastructure american materials workers senior member committee secured million new federal funding part bill support transportation priorities congressional districti look forward voting invest america act transportation infrastructure committee today vote pass house representatives coming weeksread belowtransportationhousegovinvest america house committee transportation infrastructure

name: Brad Sherman
content:
For half a century, America has successfully persuaded Japan, South Korea and Taiwan to forgo efforts to obtain nuclear weapons. This effort has been successful, even though our three allies face real threats from countries that possess nuclear weapons.

North Korea threatens South Korea. China threatens Taiwan. Japan faces concerns about both. China has hardly shown its gratitude for our efforts. It has subsidized North Korea and thereby subsidized the North Korean nuclear program.

China's bellicose attacks against Taiwan make it more difficult to persuade that country to forgo nuclear weapons.

I’m deeply concerned by the Pakistan Telecommunications Authority’s (PTA) efforts to target the global Ahmadiyya Muslim Community, including U.S. entities and representatives, for exercising their right to freedom of religion. Despite Pakistan’s longstanding promises to protect human rights and preserve religious freedoms, the Government’s legal actions against foreign entities demonstrate a troubling inclination to extend its problematic blasphemy and anti-Ahmadi laws beyond its borders.

Furthermore, the lack of transparency in ongoing cases further delegitimizes Pakistan’s claims and casts doubt on its ability to uphold judicial integrity. I call on the Government of Pakistan to cease its actions against the global Ahmadiyya Muslim Community and commit to protecting religious liberties and beleaguered communities.

content:
As we kick-off the inaugural year of the UN Decade of Ocean Science, we must rapidly scale up ocean observation and exploration efforts to better understand how to protect our ocean for future generations.

The BLUE GLOBE Act will help produce the accurate ocean data that coastal communities rely on for navigation and port security and to forecast ocean acidification, harmful algal blooms, hypoxia, and marine heat waves.

I am grateful to be working with my House Oceans Caucus Co-Chair, Don Young, on this critical issue so we can safeguard our ocean and planet.

name: Brett Guthrie
content:
The Chinese Communist Party is not being transparent about information related to COVID-19’s origins. This is completely unacceptable.

I’ve been requesting information from U.S. federal agencies and organizations as part of the COVID-19 origins investigation being led by the Energy and Commerce Committee to see what information we can uncover. Yesterday I joined my colleagues on the Energy and Commerce Committee to ask the CDC for an update on investigative studies so we can see if COVID-19 was in the United States before January 20, 2020, which is the official date. This info can help determine when the first cases of COVID-19 in China occurred. COVID-19 is responsible for more than 595,000 deaths in the U.S. We need to get to the bottom of COVID-19’s origins so we can ensure this doesn’t happen again.

name: Paul Tonko
content:
As the Biden Administration works to address the well-being of the unaccompanied children in its care, we cannot forget that we are still dealing with the fallout of the previous Administration’s actions.

A report released this week by the Interagency Task Force on the Reunification of Families found that more than 3,900 children were separated from their families as a result of the Trump Administration’s “zero tolerance” policy. The results of that cruel policy were devastating and the repercussions are still being felt by all involved.

A September 2019 HHS Office of Inspector General report found that while all unaccompanied children have experienced some type of trauma, those children who were unexpectedly separated from their parents exhibited “more fear, feelings of abandonment, and post-traumatic stress” than other children in ORR’s care.

• Ms. Chang, you were not involved in that policy, but you have devoted your career to child welfare. What can you tell us about the effects of the trauma those children experienced and likely continue to struggle with?

This Committee's investigation last Congress found that career HHS staffers were sounding the alarm about family separations and imploring HHS’s political leadership not to allow it to happen, but those warnings were not heeded.

• Ms. Chang, can you tell us what effect that policy and that whole era had on the morale of HHS employees who have dedicated their careers to the welfare of these children? And how is the Administration working to repair that relationship and empower these civil servants?

Finally, I’d like to turn to the effects on ORR care providers.

The September 2019 HHS OIG report found that the family separation policy made the jobs of ORR providers more difficult. One program director interviewed said, “We’re [seen as] the enemy.”

• Ms. Chang, can you speak about the lasting impact that the family separation policy had on ORR care providers and what the Biden Administration is doing to rebuild trust in ORR?

It is clear that thousands of children and families continue to live with the pain of that terrible policy. I appreciate all the work that the Biden Administration and civil servants across the government are doing to correct those injustices, and learn from the mistakes of that failed policy.

“When I went on a field trip to Washington, DC in 8th grade, I learned a lot about what it took to build this country and what it takes to defend it. Meeting Congressman Aguilar and seeing Congress in action that day inspired me to think about how I could serve my own community and give back to the teachers, advisors and mentors who’d done so much for me. When the Congressman came to my high school a few years later to give us information about the service academy process, I knew that this was a way I could give back to the community and the country. Ever since then, my focus has been on service and I know the Naval Academy is going to give me that opportunity to serve and to lead. name: Stephen F. Lynch
content:
Yesterday the Oversight Dems Committee held a hearing to examine the Sackler family’s role in fueling America’s devastating opioid epidemic and how our bill, the SACKLER Act, can help provide accountability moving forward. Members of the Sackler family have inflicted irreparable harm on American families and communities for years while they profited from the sale of the highly addictive painkiller OxyContin through Purdue Pharma. In 2005, I filed legislation to ban OxyContin because the Sackler family and Purdue Pharma were lying to the public about the dangers of OxyContin. Now, almost 20 years later, we are still working to hold them accountable. The SACKLER Act would ensure that bad actors like the Sackler family would not be able to avoid personal liability by using the bankruptcy laws to shield their ill-gotten billions. I thank all the witnesses for their testimony today, especially Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey for pursuing justice on behalf of victims families.

YOUTUBE.COM
Second Hearing on Sackler Family’s Role in Opioid Crisis and Need for Reform

name: Mark DeSaulnier
content:
Very proud of Contra Costa VSO for earning this national achievement award for providing exemplary assistance to veterans and their families. This recognition is well deserved for the innovative and effective ways the Office has supported our community’s veterans. Veterans' Voices

Veterans' Voices
May 25 at 4:28 PM ·

It is with great pride and honor to receive this recognition from Contra Costa County.

Contra Costa County Veterans Service Office Earns National Achievement Award for Virtual Veterans Service Office

Martinez, CA (May 25, 2021) – Contra Costa County has been recognized with an Achievement Award from the National Association of Counties (NACo). The award honors innovative, effective county government programs that strengthen services for residents.

NACo recognized the virtual Veterans Service Office for its innovativeness in extending claims representation to Veterans and their families. The virtual office is accessible from the County’s Veterans Service Office website at www.contracosta.ca.gov/vets. In the virtual office, Veterans can receive assistance from an accredited Veterans Service Representative with filing for VA benefits. In addition, a representative from the Department of Veterans Affairs is available Tuesday to assist Veterans with direct deposit, address updates, and MST claims. The virtual office is open Mondays thru Thursdays 9am – 12pm & 1pm – 6pm, and Fridays 9am – 12pm.

Nathan Johnson, County Veterans Service Officer, encourages all Veterans to utilize the virtual office when it is more convenient for them to do so. “The virtual Veterans Service Office has become a more accessible way for Veterans and their families to receive assistance. I am very proud of our team for their innovativeness, and I thank them for their hard work in building this platform,” Johnson said.

NACo President Gary Moore said, “Over the past year, county officials and frontline employees have demonstrated bold, inspirational leadership. This year’s Achievement Award winning programs illustrate the innovative ways counties build healthy, safe and vibrant communities across America.”

Nationally, awards are given in 18 different categories that reflect the vast, comprehensive services counties provide. The categories include children and youth, criminal justice and public safety, county administration, information technology, health, civic engagement and many more. Started in 1970, NACo’s annual Achievement Awards program is designed to recognize county government innovations. Each nominee is judged on its own merits and not against other applications received.

Contra Costa County Veterans Services

name: Lisa Murkowski
content: Today during a Senate Interior Appropriations hearing to discuss the FY22 budget request for the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), I raised the topic of protections for the Bristol Bay watershed. Last week I had an opportunity to visit Dillingham to begin discussions with stakeholders on what is best for the region. I was able to reiterate my commitment to developing a long-term, durable solution, and begin the process to develop a legislative proposal based off of input from regional stakeholders. I have always said that we should not pick one resource over another. I was also clear in my concerns about the use of the 404(c) veto for the Pebble deposit. I called on EPA Administrator Regan to work with me on legislative protections rather than relying solely on heavy handed administrative approaches.

name: Debbie Dingell
content:
We introduced the HALT Drunk Driving Act to ensure that what happened to the Abbas family would never happen again. When our community lost the Abbas family, I remember the pain-stricken faces of Ali, Isabella, and Giselle’s young classmates. They came to me with tears in their eyes pleading: ‘If technology exists to prevent this, why aren’t we doing something about this in Washington?

Another life was taken today in Michigan’s 12th District because this critical technology is not yet on our roads. By installing this prevention technology in all vehicles, we can save over 9,400 lives each year – we must work to get it engaged immediately.

We can’t wait any longer to make our roads safer. I’m committed to continuing to work with advocacy groups, the auto industry, and federal regulators so we can stop these preventable deaths and ensure accidents like this morning’s don’t impact yet another community.

https://www.mlive.com/news/2021/06/wrong-way-driver-dies-after-crashing-head-on-into-car-on-i-94.html

MLIVE.COM
Wrong-way driver dies after crashing head-on into car on I-94

name: Ann Kuster
content:
Less than half of unaccompanied children in immigration court are represented by an attorney — leaving boys and girls, many of whom have fled unthinkable trauma and violence, all alone in an American courtroom. It’s a fundamental violation of due process and a miscarriage of justice that the fate of a child fleeing gang and sexual violence hinges on whether they are lucky enough to receive legal representation.

We can and must do better to ensure no children are left to fend for themselves in the U.S. court system.
text: less half unaccompanied children immigration court represented attorney leaving boys girls many fled unthinkable trauma violence alone american courtroom fundamental violation due process miscarriage justice fate child fleeing gang sexual violence hinges whether lucky enough receive legal representationwe must better ensure children left fend us court system

name: Michael T. McCaul
content: June is Alzheimer’s and brain health awareness month - a time to spread hope awareness for those living with this disease. My mother battled Alzheimer’s for years before her passing, and I know how this disease and other dementias affect those suffering and their loved ones. This month and every month I’m committed to the fight against this disease and will continue to advocate for brain health.

name: Jackie Walorski
content:
We need to know more about life-threatening complications of the chemical abortion pill mifepristone. In addition to killing an unborn child, this drug can cause heavy bleeding and serious infections for women. Yet providers are only required to report patient deaths, but not hospitalization, transfusion, or other serious events.

Yesterday in a W&M hearing I pressed HHS Secretary Becerra to prioritize better data collection for this drug so we’ll have a clear picture of the potential risks it poses to women.

Homelessness affects over 580,000 people and has reached crisis proportions in major cities. Prior to the pandemic, homelessness was on the rise again in America. Service members put their lives on the line to keep us safe, secure, and free — so it’s absolutely unacceptable that many service members and their families are exposed to toxic chemicals on military bases here at home. U.S. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand
June 8 at 1:37 PM ·

name: Doris O. Matsui
content:
As a co-chair of the House Democrats Congressional Task Force on Aging & Families, it was an honor today to join Michelle Nevins, the Executive Director of the Del Oro Caregiver Resource Center and a familiar face in #Sacramento, to discuss the importance of caregivers, who are disproportionately women and people of color, in our communities.

Care work is #infrastructure because it’s what makes all other work possible. Care work gets seniors and people with disabilities the support they need to live with dignity and independence at home and in their communities. Furthermore, it’s past time that we support this vital workforce with better wages and benefits for our caregivers, who are predominantly women and women of color.

President Biden's #AmericanRescuePlan signed into law in March included new funding to support Medicaid home and community-based services, and the #AmericanJobsPlan will make additional critical investments in care infrastructure that serve our most vulnerable Californians. I’m working hard to include these related proposals in a Congressional infrastructure package.

#Caregivers are the foundation of our economy — no one can do their job if their loved ones aren’t cared for.

#CareEconomy

IRS has begun sending letters to more than 36 million American families who, based on tax returns filed with the agency, may be eligible to receive monthly Child Tax Credit payments starting in July. If you haven't done so, be sure to submit as soon as possible so you can receive any advance payment you are eligible for. IRS will begin issuing advance Child Tax Credit payments on July 15, Aug. 13, Sept. 15, Oct. 15, Nov. 15 and Dec. 15.

We need sweeping, multi-faceted solutions to tackle the daily gun violence plaguing our communities. Research shows that sustained funding for evidence-based programs, which are tailored for specific local contexts, and working in partnership with the affected communities can achieve significant and long-lasting reductions in gun violence.

Today I spoke before the House Appropriations Committee to advocate for increased funding for community-based violence intervention programs.

name: Paul Tonko
content:
The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has two programs focused on building manufacturing capabilities in regions across the United States – Manufacturing USA and the Hollings Manufacturing Extension Partnership (MEP).

The network of 11 New York MEP centers cultivates the growth of high-tech industry and helps smaller manufacturers modernize. These independent, not-for-profit organizations share a common commitment to providing direct, strategic assistance to companies in the areas of entrepreneurship, technology commercialization, product development, high-tech business incubator management, and technology transfer services.

New York State and the Capital Region are strong examples of where these programs have helped facilitate the integration of innovation and technology throughout the region’s economic development efforts. It is estimated that in Fiscal Year 2020, New York’s MEP program saw the creation or retention of over 5,000 jobs and over $214 million in new client investments.

Q: Mr. Berglund: What do you see as the role of the Manufacturing USA program and the Manufacturing Extension Partnership in regional innovation efforts?

Q: Mr. Berglund: Are MEP centers necessary partners in building new regional innovation economies?

Q: Mr. Berglund: How can we at the federal level best support these programs so that they can continue to benefit the communities in which they are located?

Q: Mr. Berglund: In your testimony, you mention that evaluation requirements for new investments in technology hubs should follow the lead of the Manufacturing Extension Partnership and some of the NSF-funded centers that do annual evaluations. Why do you think that MEP is a good model for evaluations of programs that invest in regional innovation economies?
text: national institute standards technology nist two programs focused building manufacturing capabilities regions across united states manufacturing usa hollings manufacturing extension partnership mepthe network new york mep centers cultivates growth hightech industry helps smaller manufacturers modernize independent notforprofit organizations share common commitment providing direct strategic assistance companies areas entrepreneurship technology commercialization product development hightech business incubator management technology transfer servicesnew york state capital region strong examples programs helped facilitate integration innovation technology throughout regions economic development efforts estimated fiscal year new yorks mep program saw creation retention jobs million new client investmentsq mr berglund see role manufacturing usa program manufacturing extension partnership regional innovation effortsq mr berglund mep centers necessary partners building new regional innovation economiesq mr berglund federal level best support programs continue benefit communities locatedq mr berglund testimony mention evaluation requirements new investments technology hubs follow lead manufacturing extension partnership nsffunded centers annual evaluations think mep good model evaluations programs invest regional innovation economies

name: Jim Costa
content:
We cannot continue to live on the investments that past generations have made on America’s infrastructure. We must work together on a bipartisan effort to build modern, sustainable infrastructure for a 21st century economy.

The Problem Solvers Caucus - a bipartisan group of members of Congress that I have been a part of since the beginning - is once again working to develop a framework that we hope will result in a package that can pass in Congress and be signed into law by the President.

We have critical needs throughout the country. In my district in the San Joaquin Valley, we must invest for our future water needs, improve our transportation system - including building High Speed Rail - and enhancing access to broadband. There’s much more of course that needs to be done for our schools and healthcare systems - such as building a medical school - that are needed investments for the people of our valley.

PROBLEMSOLVERSCAUCUS.HOUSE.GOV
Problem Solvers Caucus Unveils "Building Bridges: A Bipartisan Physical Infrastructure Framework"
text: cannot continue live investments past generations made americas infrastructure must work together bipartisan effort build modern sustainable infrastructure 21st century economythe problem solvers caucus bipartisan group members congress part since beginning working develop framework hope result package pass congress signed law presidentwe critical needs throughout country district san joaquin valley must invest future water needs improve transportation system including building high speed rail enhancing access broadband theres much course needs done schools healthcare systems building medical school needed investments people valleyproblemsolverscaucushousegovproblem solvers caucus unveils building bridges bipartisan physical infrastructure framework

name: Albio Sires
content:
I just spoke at the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure markup in support of the #INVESTAct. This bill provides critical funding for surface transportation across the US, especially #NJ8. US infrastructure is currently graded a C-. This investment is long overdue.

I also discussed the need to move forward on the Gateway Tunnel project. Tens of thousands of commuters rely on tunnels which were damaged during Hurricane Sandy. I look forward to partnering with the Biden admin and my colleagues in New Jersey.

Last Congress, I was proud to support necessary infrastructure investment, but the Senate refused to even vote on it. We can’t afford any more delays. Our infrastructure needs are costly and we need to pass federal funding.
text: spoke house committee transportation infrastructure markup support investact bill provides critical funding surface transportation across us especially nj8 us infrastructure currently graded c investment long overduei also discussed need move forward gateway tunnel project tens thousands commuters rely tunnels damaged hurricane sandy look forward partnering biden admin colleagues new jerseylast congress proud support necessary infrastructure investment senate refused even vote cant afford delays infrastructure needs costly need pass federal funding

name: U.S. Helsinki Commission
content:
In 2016, Helsinki Commission Chair Senator Ben Cardin reflected on the work of commissioners in a Congressional Record statement:

“The hard work we do on the Helsinki Commission is not a job requirement for a Member of Congress. Rather than being a responsibility, it is something many of us choose to do because it is rewarding to secure the release of a longtime political prisoner, to reunify a family, to observe elections in a country eager to learn the meaning of democracy for the first time, to enable individuals to worship in accordance with their faiths, to know that policies we advocated have meant increased freedom for millions of individuals in numerous countries, and to present the United States as a force for positive change in this world.”

#HelsinkiComm45

CSCE.GOV
40th Anniversary of the U.S. Helsinki Commission
text: helsinki commission chair senator ben cardin reflected work commissioners congressional record statementthe hard work helsinki commission job requirement member congress rather responsibility something many us choose rewarding secure release longtime political prisoner reunify family observe elections country eager learn meaning democracy first time enable individuals worship accordance faiths know policies advocated meant increased freedom millions individuals numerous countries present united states force positive change worldhelsinkicomm45cscegov40th anniversary us helsinki commission

name: David B. McKinley
content:
While most of the attention has been paid to the COVID pandemic in the last year, our nation’s substance abuse epidemic has grown event worse. Yet, our healthcare system still unnecessarily encourages the use of opioids. The NOPAIN Act would ensure that non-opioid options to treat and manage pain are not put at a disadvantage. While pain management for all patients should be handled between a patient and doctor, opioids should not be the first or only option given.

https://www.theintelligencer.net/opinion/editorials/2021/06/congress-should-act-on-opioid-plan/

THEINTELLIGENCER.NET
Congress Should Act on Opioid Plan
text: attention paid covid pandemic last year nations substance abuse epidemic grown event worse yet healthcare system still unnecessarily encourages use opioids nopain act would ensure nonopioid options treat manage pain put disadvantage pain management patients handled patient doctor opioids first option giventheintelligencernetcongress act opioid plan

name: John Katko
content:
I reintroduced the Preliminary Damage Assessment Improvement Act, a bill that would deliver reliable and consistent assistance to communities impacted by flooding, including Lake Ontario’s shoreline communities. When disaster strikes, time is of the essence. Unfortunately, due to constraints at FEMA, federal relief for disaster-impacted communities can be unnecessarily delayed. My bipartisan bill takes important steps to enhance FEMA’s ability to provide federal relief to disaster-impacted communities.

AUBURNPUB.COM
Rep. John Katko looks to address delays in federal disaster relief
text: reintroduced preliminary damage assessment improvement act bill would deliver reliable consistent assistance communities impacted flooding including lake ontarios shoreline communities disaster strikes time essence unfortunately due constraints fema federal relief disasterimpacted communities unnecessarily delayed bipartisan bill takes important steps enhance femas ability provide federal relief disasterimpacted communitiesauburnpubcomrep john katko looks address delays federal disaster relief

Full Committee Chairwoman Maxine Waters and Ranking Member McHenry host a virtual hearing entitled, “Universal Vouchers: Ending Homelessness and Expanding Economic Opportunity in America."

- - - - - - - -
Witnesses for this one-panel hearing will be:

• Ann Oliva, Senior Fellow, Center on Budget and Policy Priorities

• Mary Cunningham, Vice President, Metropolitan Housing and Communities Policy, Urban Institute

• Benjamin Metcalf, Managing Director, Terner Center for Housing Innovation, UC Berkeley

• Chancela Al-Mansour, Executive Director, Housing Rights Center

• Howard Husock, Adjunct Scholar, Domestic Policy, American Enterprise Institute

See more here: https://go.usa.gov/x6Zf4
